values:
Do I not like disco because I'm racist?

...Is my first thought upon finding out that disco had its roots in African-American, Latino, and gay communities in New York.  What have I internalized?!

"Athena, it's funny you're not pregnant yet."
"Yeah, well, I guess nobody's tried to make me."

I didn't like him, either.

Why didn't he call?

"I saw your CouchSurfing profile.  You are so cool."

Nevermind that he's known me for six months already.

Left the symphony at intermission to see the ten o'clock showing of Bridesmaids.  Wearing a pretty dress.

It was the right choice.

"Your cards have famous ladies from American history on them?  Girl, that's some Liz Lemon shit right there."

Yesss!
I might be confusing being an Anglophile with watching a lot of BBC on Netflix.

In asking the kiddies to prove they had attended a workshop, I asked them to describe the speaker.  Three times out of three "Fat" was their first adjective.

To be fair, she's kinda ugly in a nondescript way, so they couldn't really have gone with that, either.

I've reached an age where indigestion can keep me up at night.

Also, Cloyne makes my skin dry.
So, apparently I have a "big personality."  And "some people think I'm a bitch."

The Morgan definition of love?  Making fun of you so no one else can hear.

Harm Reduction classes make me want to cry.  Picking favorites between the narcoleptic pug/Reverend and the sanctimonious faith-based shelter volunteer, yeah, great.

Failed at my first attempt at making stock.  Should I be one of those people I hate and take a culinary class?  At least it won't be pretentious.  JC classes in Decatur, IL, not so much with the pretension.  

I have to move into the co-op.  I don't know if I'll make it.  Ask for a raise?  These career advise e-newsletters I get say part salary inequity is a result of women not asking for raises like men do.  I don't want to be one of those.  Also don't want to milk the organization when failing would be so easy.

I have hipster glasses and a nose ring now.

Vacation to Detroit/Ann Arbor coming up, woo!

Dentist gave me a referral for an orthodontist and says I've ground my teeth to sextegenarian levels.  Mouth guard on the way.  I just keep getting sexier.

Why force me to download iTunesU video podcasts when no visual aids are used and John Merriman has the biggest combover this side of 1985?

Sacramento isn't as horrible as I remembered.  Public transit and the sprawl made things difficult as a teen is all.

I know that I make it difficult to be my friend, but I expected more of my high school comrades.  The ones who had the time weren't willing to leave their houses; the others didn't bother to return my call. 

House number one.  The arrival: 4 dudes in varying states of undress and 49ers gear.  Apparently the plan is to watch the game.  Okay.  "Do you have any booze?  Because I'm gonna need to drink."  He brings some jokes, the one-man show tirades that I loved him for.  Ultimately I end up caving to the peer pressure that hasn't eased since high school, take a hit from the bong and promptly want to die for the rest of the evening.  This eases only slightly when I yack on his driveway. 

Having seen the bachelor bathtub, I opt for a Motel 6.  I wake up only once with terrors of bedbugs.  That's until I wake up the next morning, with my brain still angry about last night. 

House number two.  I manage not to pet my old schoolmate's child.  I might not even refer to him as an "it" again, now that it talks.  Oh, wait.  

Discussions of perpetual unemployment and failed community classes ensue.  And then alcoholism and house arrest and the ins and outs of the legal system as learned from personal experience.  I know I said that ambition isn't important, but its reverse is still disappointing.  

Lessons learned: my car can go 75mph for an hour and a half, my sweet new rollerblades fit, racism still exists (and in people I know), I would have more boyfriends if I lived in Sacramento, and Jimboys is delicious,  Not that I didn't already know that Jimboys is delicious.

New age-inappropriate things that I enjoy that prove I am, in fact, an old lady.

1.  Prunes
I've been so excited about prunes I had to kind of restrain myself from talking to the old lady in line in front of me at Andronico's.  Prunes, so delicious they're dangerous.
2.  The AAA Magazine
Seriously, has anybody looked at it?

You know, it's really hard to make pleasant chitchat, when what's going on with you includes:

1. Job blowing up again, and times three.  Largest co-op in North America, on my shoulders, okay.
2.  Houseguest all up in my grill, even if I love her.
3.  Bike stolen.
4.  Car wiggy.
5.  Ex apparently very happily in love, and with a girl not particularly gorgeous, so apparently it was actually my personality.  Oh, and I find this out (SURPRISE!) in a rather small room.  At least I didn't look like my usual barfy self.
6.  Nobody wants to date me, ever.  Which is why the above still bothers me.
7.  There is apparently no con-free method of removing my lady facial hair.
8.  I talk about rape for at least six hours a week.
9.  Knowing your bra size doesn't help you find good bras when you have to buy them all online.
10.  I can't stop saying like.  Everybody else says it too, but I don't care.  Its horrible.

Under great stress, my mouth goes dry and my feet go sweaty.

I guess I couldn't have evaded stress forever!
Once, for show and tell, in front of a whole class, I did a little experiment showing surface tension on water.
So, not to get on the bandwagon a decade late or anything, but the West Wing is SO GOOD.
Coffee with friend, Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, Fisherman's Wharf, and Isabel Point.
A bra that fits.  Only 4 inches and 6 cups different than the usual.

The definition of insanity:  doing the same thing over and over, expecting a different outcome.

That's what he said.

Leaving for vacation and the Ozarks on Friday.  I've barely been out of Berkeley for the last 9 months (since the job), haven't been out of the bay area in a year, and not out of California in a year and a half.  Wow.  I really hope I don't end up being one of those people who puts off leaving so long that they never go (if for no other reason than to meet some people who haven't heard any of my jokes).

I wish I was going somewhere a little more glamorous, but I gotta see Mom on at least a yearly basis.  Still glad I don't have to winter in Illinois anymore, even if not having someone make a fuss over you on your birthday hurts the heart a bit.

For awhile there, I really thought that I wouldn't be able to hold out much longer. Any day now, and I'd have to call him, to hang out, to make each other laugh.

He wasn't trying to be cruel, even if that's how it turned out. He just couldn't love me. And I kept my word and wasn't in love with him, either. But he kept us there so long. Me, waiting for a sign, any sign. Him, waiting for inspiration to strike?

A few weeks ago I wrote him a letter, I was so sure. I was glib. What says "let's be friends again soon" like Mexican folk art?, I said.  But I didn't mail it, because I wanted to leave it for him.   And I kept meaning to drive by.  And then I drove by, but I didn't know I would be.  Or I had forgotten it.  Or it was in my other bag.

And then I started to actually miss him.  I felt the lack of him.  Like I just noticed that part of me he did make happy wasn't happy anymore.  And now it doesn't make sense to see him.
The first time I've taken my own picture and seen my mom in it.

Someone is sneaking into my apartment and drinking my coffee and using my skin cream.  

Maybe they're the one dirtying all these dishes...

It's a weird feeling when the friend you hardly wanted gets all charming, reminding you of the days when you thought you'd like to kiss him on the mouth.  

Weirder that his other BFFslashyourBFF feels the same way.

Add in the occasional innuendo and it makes for downright consternation.


In other news, I might be okay with hugs except with people I've ever thought about naked or thought I might ever see as such.

I'm kind of a professional grown-up.
I have an economist crush on Paul Krugman.
I mostly get (busy) crushes on younger boys.  Oh, to leave this college town.
Went on a date with an internet person.  I wish funny was more negotiable.
Can't decide whether or not to change what makes me unhappy on the chance it's not really what makes me unhappy.
Fucking cellulite.
Spent with two very platonic ladies at the Exploratorium, a pillow fight, and a local get-drunk-while-you-eat sort of place.  Celibacy never felt so good.

"Our relationship has always been tumultuous."
"What do you mean?  Tumultuous?  I make bean soup!  I am not tumultuous."

"Athena, I feel like you don't like me.  Is there some history here I don't know about?"
"Nope" accompanied by whaddaya-gonna-do shrug.  "You can't win 'em all.  And you have plenty of admirers."

Squawking ensues.

I know I'm not the only person who enjoys a little unreasonable antipathy.  Some people just rub you wrong, and there are enough other people out there that I don't need to put the effort into changing that.

Not that I usually put all that out there, but if somebody's going to hassle me about why I'm not giving them the number to the phone I already don't like answering...  Boom.

Currently, four guys I've dated have gone on to marry their next partner.  Did I ruin dating for them?

Maybe I just need to stop dating older.  

Oh wait, not dating.

How do you respond when someone tells you that, despite his best efforts for the better part of a year, it's impossible to love you. Return his DVD, but broken in two with a bow on top. Obviously. Yes, Facebook, remove all connection. Make it like it never happened.
Prrrreeeetty sure I let out a pretty-drunk mostly-asleep "I love you."

Crying on my way home about how nobody will ever love me or help me fix my flat tire, and I get home to two messages.  One about my tire, one inviting me to lasagna.  Thanks for not making me want to totally kill myself, world.
How can I keep breaking up with a boy that's never my boyfriend?

He told me he loved me, and I cried more in front of him  than I have any guy ever.

We agreed we should be friends.  And that we don't really want to just be friends.  But that's besides the point.
This couch was so close to being mine.

Prologue "What's this scar? It's scary." Eyebrow. "That's from my heart surgery when I was a kid. I told you that." "No. What was wrong?" "I had a hole in my heart." So matter of fact. Pause. I giggle. "What?" "You had a hole in your heart before you met me." Yesterday Inbox: Captain Fall-Down, no subject. I miss you. I hope you're doing well. Email being too personal, I get a card and a bottle of honey. Clandestine doorstep drop-off. Inside: "I miss you, too. Plus I had this card that looked like a rooster, and this honey shaped like a bear, and I thought you might like that." Inbox: Captain Fall-Down, no subject "You're so sweet to a bastard. I wish I had been here when you dropped the card and honey by. It would have made my day to see your face...and also to hear some snippy remark about the hole in my heart. You're too good to me sweets." But I won't reply.

She's 23, but I can't help but feel like she's oversexualized.  Just a young woman in perpetually slutty makeup.

Maybe I'm just getting old.  25 this Christmas!
